w:r.w:t: The teacher will teach feeling words by using TPR, sentence frames, and vocabulary. Students will study these words and phrases:
cow, horse, bunny, rabbit, pig, sheep, hen, horse, duck apple, ball, like, love; I like animals; I love dogs; A ________ is an animal; What do you see?; I see ___________.
At the completion of this lesson, students will be able to:
Recognize, spell, and pronounce the words for different animals
Spell and pronounce commonly associated words.
Spell and pronounce words with the “r” sound and double letters.
Use sets of words in complete sentences.
Word List: cow, horse, bunny, rabbit, pig, sheep, hen, horse, duck apple, ball, like, love
This slide will always be the
-branded opener slide that the teacher will display as the student enters the classroom.
Greet your student and introduce the lesson concept: Today, we are going to be learning about different animals.
Do sounds that represent different animals.
and spell it for students on the screen. Have students repeat and spell the word out on the screen or on a separate piece of paper.
Ask students, “Which picture is an animal?”. Circle an animal as an example. Have students find and help you label the rest.
Visual/audio cue: Act out each animal according to their typical actions and sounds. Have students repeat after you.

Explain to students that like is a good feeling that we have to different things.

Have students draw a picture of something they like on the screen.

Explain to students that love is also a good feeling that we have to different things.

and write out it’s spelling. Have students repeat your actions.
Circle the cow in the picture.
Have students repeat the phrase and circling action.
Show students what sound a cow makes and have them repeat it.
Do the sound that a horse makes.
and write out it’s spelling. Have students repeat your actions.
Circle the horse in the picture.
Have students repeat the phrase and circling action.
Show students what sound a horse makes and have them repeat it.
Do the action that a bunny does.
and write out it’s spelling. Have students repeat your actions.
Circle the bunny in the picture.
Have students repeat the phrase and circling action.
Show students how a bunny looks (
put two hands above your head to look like ears and make your teeth look like buck teeth) or how a bunny moves (i.e. hopping with two feet close together).
Do the sound that a pig does.
and write out it's spelling. Have students repeat your actions.
Circle the pig in the picture.
Have students repeat the phrase and circling action.
and write out it's spelling. Have students repeat your actions.
Circle the sheep in the picture.
Have students repeat the phrase and circling action.
Show students how a sheep sounds (i.e. “bah”).
Do the sound that a hen does.
and write out it's spelling. Have students repeat your actions.
Circle the hen in the picture. Tell students that a hen is a chicken, and a type of bird.
Have students repeat the phrase and circling action.
Do the sound that a duck does.
and write out it's spelling. Have students repeat your actions.
Circle the duck in the picture. Tell students that a duck is a type of bird.
Have students repeat the phrase and circling action.
Circle and spell other words that have double letters
Circle the bunny and explain that some words need double letters.

Give students different examples of words with the r sound (read, red, room, run,
) to see how they do with pronouncing this sound.

Kinesthetic Cue: Help students with preparing their mouths for making an “r” sound. Some tips include biting gently down on their tongues to help them remember that their tongues need to press against their molars. Practice warming up with other similar sounds that use the same motion.

. Have students repeat and write out the spelling on the screen or on a separate piece of paper. Have students underline the “r” and point to it. Explain that this is the letter that makes the “r” sound.
Ask student: What do you see?
Shrug shoulders and raise intonation when hitting the question mark,, point toward the student for “you”, put hand above eyes for “see”.
Provide student with a sentence frame to help them answer:

Freeform “Show and Tell” Conversation Activity Slide 21
Students should have a blank slide to draw a picture of different activities on teacher prompts.
cow, horse, bunny, pig, sheep, hen, horse, duck, rabbit, apple, ball, like, love
Teacher will prompt student to draw a picture to represent different activities through pictures. One prompt at a time.
Teacher will write words from the lesson (
cow, horse, bunny, pig, sheep, hen, horse, duck, rabbit, apple, ball, like, love)
Students will read and spell their new words: (
cow, horse, bunny, pig, sheep, hen, horse, duck, rabbit, apple, ball, like, love)
Teacher will give feedback on the spelling and pronunciation of the new words.
